numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I looked at the graphic.
2. For each form of communication, young women reach out to their parents more often than young men.
3. The forms of communication are texting and phone calls and in-person visits.
4. Young women send texts to their parents more often than young men.
5. Young women talk on the phone with their parents more often than young men.
6. Young women send texts or talk on the phone with their parents about 25% more frequently than young men.
7. Young women and young men visit their parents in person with similar frequency.
8. The difference in in-person visit frequency is about 5%.
9. Texting is the most frequent form of communication for young women.
10. Texting is the most frequent form of communication for young men.
11. I wonder why women tend to reach out more to their parents.
12. I wonder which parent young people reach out to more overall.
13. I call my mother almost every day.
14. I call my mother to keep her updated on my college life.
15. My mother tells my father the updates.
16. This pattern probably varies from person to person.
17. It would be interesting to see the variation.
18. I have a brother.
19. I reach out to my parents more often than my brother reaches out to my parents.
20. I am the second child.
21. I rely on my parents for some things.
22. This reliance could be a reason for my behavior.
23. I am a young woman.
24. My brother is a young man.
25. My gender could be a reason for my behavior.
26. My brother and I represent these statistics.
27. Many boy-girl sibling relationships show a similar pattern.
28. The headline is: Communication Trends: How Youth Stay Connected with Parents Across Genders.
